title: Lem/Leme
common:
André L. FR. Clayes research suggests Lem Gilles as the patriarch of the family in Bugres (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 59).

Luiz G. Silva Leme propose that the name origin has relationship with "argila ou grêda" (Silva Leme, Luiz G., Vol. II, pp. 179), but André L. FR. Clayes' research suggests that the family name as first name of Willem, or it is a contraction (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 6-7).

In this project we only call attention to some contradictions, for more knowledge about the family, it is suggested to study Margarida O. R. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008) and André L. FR. Clayes (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012).

families.name: Leme
history: The Leme's family begins in Portugal with business and Lem Maerten I's migration (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 44-49 ; Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 60-62).

people.name: Lem Maerten I
history: Portuguese authors normally translate his name (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 44-49 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 3), but this project names him as he was in Bugres.

It is also necessary to clarify a marriage that did not happen. According to André L. FR. Clayes, the fact that authors do not know Dutch language, Lem Maerten I's language, conduct them to affirm that he also had a marriage in Flanders, but the person that had marriage was his homonymous son (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61).
In the Armeiro Mor's book, that has a beautiful coat of arms, but it does not have its documentation, exposes the Lem Maerten I's arms (do Cró, João , 1509, fl. 110 (img. 235)).

The Afonso V's chancellery informs that Lem Maerten I's authorized his Jewish creditors to be sent to Christianity justice (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 48 ; Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 63v (img. 98)).
One of his sons, Rui Leme, appears as a witness in treaty of Tordesillas (Tratado de Tordesillas (Folio 6r)).

marriages.name: Joana Barroso
history: According to André L. FR. Clayes (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61-62, 66, 71). Emanuel Soeiro (Sueyro, Emanuel, pp. 494) and Henrique H. de Noronha (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 41) also cite this marriage.

This marriage is considered as hypothetical, because there is a legitimation letter of a Martim Leme with his brothers and sisters. He could be a half-brother, or he was legitimated independent of to be a different mother, of finally this marriage did not happen.

marriages.name: Leonor Rodrigues
history: She did not have marriage with Lem Maerten I (Arquivo Municipal de Lisboa, doc. 24 PT/AMLSB/CMLSBAH/ADM/002/0284/0022), but she was mother (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 47-48) of 7 of his legitimated children (Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 66v-67 (img. 104)).

marriages.name: Van Nieuwenhove Adrienne
history: She did not have marriage with Lem Maerten I, instead, she had marriage with Lem Maerten II (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61, 67, 71, 72).
She could be the person cited by Luiz G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., Vol. II, pp. 179-180).

children.name: Martim Leme
history: Probably the unique son of the first marriage (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61-62, 66, 71). The Emanuel Sueyro's propose about a marriage with a Barroso helps to understanding the confusion cited by André L. FR. Clayes (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61).
Legitimaed by his father (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 47 ; Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 67 (img. 104)).
He is treated as a hypothetical son, because we have doubts about his mother.

children.name: Antonio Leme
history: Legitimated by his father (Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 67 (img. 104)).

children.name: Rui Leme
history: Legitimated by his father (Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 67 (img. 104)).

people.name: Rui Leme
history: There is no data linked to him about any marriage or children (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 118-119).
He received the title of knight during Dom Manuel I's reign (Chancelaria Régia, Manuel I, Livro 28, fl. 110 (img. 180)).
Among his political actions, it is necessary to highlight the fact that he was a witness in Treaty of Tordesillas (Tratado de Tordesillas (Folio 6r)).

people.name: Martim Leme
history: The fact that authors do not know Dutch language conduct them to do mistakes with his father's history (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61). There is also issues to define his mother (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61 ; Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 47).
His activities in Flanders were organized through documentation by André L. FR. Clayes (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 15, 26, 31, 33, 57 ).

marriages.name: Van Nieuwenhove Adrienne
history: She did not have marriage with Len Maerten I, as it was explained above (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61, 67, 71, 72)

people.name: Antonio Leme
history: He lived during the 15th century, but only during the 20th century we started to understand more about him when Luiz P. M. de Castro published his work (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938).

Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme, following to Montarroyo, says correctly that he is a son of Lem Maerten I and Leonor Rodrigues, but he did not inform his wife's name (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp.1-2,8-9). Continuing his text, he wrote that he had a homonymous grandson that "Casou com Catharina de Barros ... filha de Pedro Gonçalves da Camara e de sua mulher Isabel de Barros.", and centuries after this, Luiz G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., Vol. II, pp. 180-182) accepted the idea, but this sentence needs a deep study:
  • Montarroyo had a confusion, because grandson and grandfather are the same person (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 5-7).
  • The marriage with a descendant of Pedro Gonçalves da Câmara did not happen. Using Henrique H. Noronha's work (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 42 ; de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 96) that cites his father-in-law testament, Luiz P. M. de Castro corrected the mistake.
  • Noronha brought us the mistake with homonymous, but he also had his own mistakes with Antonio Leme's ancestors.

He also received an arm coat like his father (Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 21, fl. 90 (img. 173)), that was copied in different papers (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 40 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M., 1938, pp. 15,16 ; Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 68).

It is possible that his brother, Rui Leme, was not the unique family member to have a relationship with the "discover" of Abya Yala/América, because as a Chronicle informs, he had a meeting with Columbus talking about supposed three islands that he observed in a navigation (de Armas, Antonio Romeu, 1971, pp. 545, 547-548).

The last mistake that is necessary to highlight has the relationship with his son Antão Leme, that is not mentioned by Henrique H. de Noronha (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 42 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 9-10). This mistake was corrected with a document of his grandson (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 16-17).

marriages.name: Desconhecida
history: According to nobiliarchy (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 42 ; Silva Leme, Luiz G., Vol. II, pp. 180-182 ; Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp.8-9).

marriages.name: Catharina de Barros
history: Her grandson's document lists her children (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 16-17), that are also cited by Henrique H. de Noronha when names her (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 42).

children.name: Antão Leme
history: According to his son document (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 16-17).
